segments.text: Hey everyone and welcome back to the
channel. So this week Stripe CEO shared
what he says is the coolest breakthrough
since GPT4 and what he's referring to
here is a new piece of research from
Cursor which saw it deploy hundreds of
different AI coding agents who each
wrote millions of lines of code. We'll
take a look at that study in more detail
and what it might mean for the future of
SAS. Also coming up this week, YouTube's
CEO reveals his somewhat contradictory
AI road map for the year ahead. leaked
new data shows us just how quickly
Gemini's API usage is growing and
Spotify tests a pretty unconventional
new growth tactic. So stay tuned for all
of that and more. And as always, if you
do enjoy the briefing, then hit the
subscribe and the like button. So Stripe
CEO Patrick Collison said that this is
the coolest breakthrough since GPT4. And
the TLDDR here is that Cursor has
figured out how to run hundreds of AI
coding agents autonomously for weeks on
end where these agents wrote millions of
lines of code. This was an experiment
where these autonomous coding agents
were tasked with various different
complex things. I'll put the link in the
description to this piece from cursor so
you can read it in more detail. But to
give you an overview, in this experiment
they asked these agents to build complex
things. So for example, in one
experiment they were asked to build an
entire browser and in another they were
asked they asked it to create a clone of
Microsoft Excel. What they found was
overall the system was far more
effective than they had originally
expected but they said that hierarchy
was essential to its performance. So to
create this hierarchy they created three
different types of agents. So they had
planner agents who continuously explored
the codebase and created task. Worker
agents picked up these tasks and focused
entirely on completing them without
coordinating with other workers. And
judge agents determined whether to
continue at the end of each cycle. Cursa
also discovered that it was GPT 5.2 that
was much better at extended autonomous
work versus the other models. And it was
also a lot better at following
instructions and maintaining focus.
These experiments are still ongoing and
I'll put the link to in the description
to the Excel clone experiment which is
still ongoing. But why does Stripe CEO
say that this is the coolest thing since
GPT4? Well, I think there are three main
reasons for this. The first is scale.
So, this scale is unprecedented. We've
seen coding assistants before, but not
hundreds of agents all autonomously
writing millions of lines of code over
weeks and producing something
functional. So, this leap from AI just
helps you to write code to AI
autonomously builds an entire browser,
for example, or Excel from scratch is
pretty massive. Anthropic CEO was at
Davos this week with the creme de la
creme of tech and he said that we're 6
to 12 months away from the stage where
the model is pretty much doing all of
the coding which of course will have a
transformative effect on product
development if he's correct of course.
The second reason is that it solves a
coordination problem that human teams
struggle with. So anyone who's worked in
product development will confirm that
even human engineering teams or
particularly human engineering teams
have trouble with coordinating with
hundreds of other developers on a single
codebase. The fact that curser says that
it's close to figuring out how to make
agents do this effectively at scale is
actually pretty exciting. This week
Sacha Nadella echoed this change in the
structure of teams when he was speaking
on the all-in podcast. So on this he
described a shift from siloed roles to a
new era where things like product
management, design and engineering are
combined to create broader full stack
builders with app teams orchestrating
multiple models by assigning roles to
them to get better results than any
other single model. And the third reason
is that this is ultimately very
practical. So unlike other research,
these techniques are already informing
Kurser's own product development process
for Stripe CEO. This has direct
implications for how his own software
gets built. And some of Stripe's own
team members have started to use AI
agents internally to help them with all
kinds of things. So Stripe's design
manager, for example, this week revealed
how he uses a vibecoded in browser
prototyping tool that he built for
himself. So AI coding agents are not
only transforming the jobs of engineers,
but gradually they're also transforming
the other jobs that product teams do
like design as well. We'll take a look
at some other examples of this in action
later in the briefing. But setting these
aside for a moment, the biggest impact
of these AI coding agents is arguably on
the SAS industry itself. If these AI
coding agents can autonomously build
complex products like browsers and
spreadsheets, then what does that mean
for the vertical SAS companies charging
premium prices for these products? This
week, a new report warned that vertical
SAS is under threat. So this is a new
RBS capital markets report and it warns
that AI is now penetrating vertical SAS
markets that were once considered AI
proof due to regulatory complexity and
domain expertise requirements. This
report says that opinions are now
shifting following the launch of three
products this past week including Claude
for healthcare and life sciences claude
cowwork and an expanded labs incubator.
As a result, shares of major software
companies like Salesforce, Workday,
Inuit, and Snowflake have all fallen
between 6 and 13%. And this report
suggested the AI overhang on software
stocks will likely persist throughout
2026. And so for product teams, the
critical strategic question is
increasingly becoming, what can you own
that an AI model can't replicate? And
speaking of AI agents, if you're
interested in learning more about the
application of AI agents during the
product development process, then you
might be interested in this latest deep
dive over on Substack. So in this deep
dive, I explore several different
examples of AI agents in practice,
including some analysis of how Door Dash
is using AI agent swarms, how Spotify is
using background coding agents in its
development efforts, how Instacart is
using design agents, and more. So check
that one out if you're interested in
learning more about the real world
applications of AI agents in product
development. Back to the briefing and
elsewhere this week, YouTube's CEO Neil
Mohan has outlined the company's product
roadmap for 2026. And if I'm honest,
it's bold, but also a little bit
contradictory. So on one hand, they're
giving creators more AI tools, including
the ability to create an AI avatar clone
that can be used in shorts. But on the
other, they're also promising to crack
down on AI slop with a commitment to
building new AI slop detection tools.
There's also a renewed focus both on
shorts, which Mohan says averages 200
billion daily active users, and also on
TV, where YouTube is now leading. The
one group that seems to be increasingly
forgotten by YouTube's product
leadership team, though, is the average
desktop user who watches longer form
videos. So a quick glance on the YouTube
home screen shows that the grid of
longer form videos has actually shrunk
with more prominence now given to
shorts. So there is a risk here that by
trying to cater to each of these
different user segments and viewing
habits, they move too far away from what
was once at least their core value
proposition. Now it's understandable why
they've made these changes because the
market is pretty much forcing them into
this position. Tik Tok has extended its
formats into long form and this week
Netflix unveiled its product roadmap for
2026 with an announcement of its plans
to overhaul its app. So this redesigned
app is set to focus more on short form
videos and podcasts. And their CEO said
that the revamp was designed to better
serve the expansion of our business over
the decade to come. So, with Netflix
announcing plans for a new short form
video app and Tik Tok expanding into
longer form videos, YouTube could see
itself squeezed further as it tries to
cater to everyone. I can't help thinking
that at this point spinning off shorts
into its own dedicated short form video
app may be a better option for YouTube
since for me at least the UX is starting
to feel a little bit overly cluttered
with too many different formats in one
place. What do you think? Let me know in
the comments below. In other news, this
week, Spotify is testing out a new
feature it calls page match, which will
allow users to scan a physical page and
start listening to an audiobook from
that page. If you remember, Spotify
previously acquired an audio company
back in 2021. And given the low margins
on music, audiobooks are potentially
much better revenue stream for the
company. So, while this feature is a
delighter in many ways, it's also a
discovery and activation tactic to try
to drum up some of that revenue. Users
don't always know what's available in
the Spotify library and so this feature
removes any friction by creating a new
entry point. So if users already own a
physical version of a book, why not try
the audio version? The question for
Spotify though is how many users who own
the physical version of a book also want
to try out the audio version?
Nonetheless, I think this is a pretty
creative attempt at product growth. And
speaking of the music industry, there
were actually two interesting updates
from 11 Labs this week that demonstrate
the impact of generative AI across other
industries including music. So this
week, 11 Labs released their very own
first album called the 11 album. This is
essentially a showcase featuring songs
from a diverse group of artists
including legendary performers like Liza
Manelli and Art Garuncle to more
contemporary artists that I don't really
know much about. And the project is
designed to demonstrate the capabilities
of 11 Labs AI music generation platform
called 11 music. The second example from
11 Labs is a new piece that it published
which shows how it created its own user
research agent. So the 11 Labs user
research agent is an AI powered
interviewer that 11 Labs built to
conduct customer interviews at scale. So
they use this to run over 230 user
interviews in just 24 hours. And this
was for a specific product, their 11
reader app. They say that an activity
that would typically take weeks or
months with human researchers when you
factor in things like scheduling,
conducting interviews and analysis can
be done in just a few days. Overall, how
are you using 11 reader today? For
example, are you listening to articles,
ebooks, fanfiction, or something else?
>> I'm primarily using it to import epubs
and to play fanfiction from different
websites.
>> That's really helpful to know. Thank
you. They used Gemini's 2.5 Flash for
this. And the agent asked a series of
structured questions covering things
like how users are using the app, what
their best and worst features were,
payment willingness, and brand
perception, which further echoes what
Microsoft CEO Sachi Nadella was saying
about the blurring of the different
roles in modern product development.
Now, let's take a look at some data and
trends from the week. And so we'll start
with this new leaked data which shows
that API calls to Gemini's models more
than doubled last year from around 35
billion calls in March 2025 to 85
billion in August of 2025. Now we've
talked a lot about the growth of Gemini
across the channel in previous weeks. So
this might not come as a surprise, but
this is an excellent proxy to show how
Gemini is increasingly being adopted by
the enterprise market. This analysis by
Menllo Ventures also echoes this
sentiment as well. And as you can see
from this graph, the market share of
leading LLM providers for pure API
adoption has increased for Google, but
it is anthropic that has grown from 12%
in 2023 to 40% in 2025. This chart is
bad news for OpenAI. And while Gemini's
adoption curve is less steep than
Anthropics, given the low switching
costs involved in switching out an API
provider, it's not unreasonable to think
that potentially Gemini may or take
Anthropic at some point in the future.
Alphabet's upcoming earnings call will
give us a closer insight into Gemini's
revenue streams. And I'll put the link
to that report in the description. And
speaking of Gemini's revenue streams,
one area that everyone is expecting to
be hit pretty badly is traditional
search driven by the rise of AI
overviews. And new analysis from Oxford
University this week says that
publishers expect traffic from search
engines to decline by around 40% over
the next 3 years. But this new analysis
from development platform Graphite
actually tells a slightly different
story. They say that while SEO traffic
has declined, it hasn't declined
dramatically. So they say it's only
declined by around 2.5%. Using data from
Similar Web, which analyzed over 40,000
different major US websites. They found
that search traffic decreased only 2.5%
yearonear and not the 25 to 60% claimed
by other reports. They also say that
search engine usage remains stable. So
traffic to Google actually increased
0.8% in 2025 and overall search engine
traffic grew 0.4%. Clicks to ads have
increased 2.1% but 90% of clicks are
still actually from organic. So this
report is painting a slightly different
picture from the previous narrative that
Google search is ultimately doomed. But
on that note, I will leave it there for
this week. Thanks very much for
listening and watching.
